author: Tammy H.

description: No flavor, no seasoning, huge super burrito with NO flavor, soggy beef that tasted boiled, gross and terrible. I work near by and walk by this place several times a week, wished I had kept walking!!!!!!!
author: Tina A.

description: Delicious! I stopped in with my family when touring downtown SF, and stumbled into this spot. We were pleasantly surprised by the quality and taste of the food, and the cozy seating upstairs. Staff was brief by friendly, and the pricing seemed to be reasonable for the area. I got the chicken burrito, and it was very filling.
author: Jesse T.

description: Got the burrito. Reheated meat, stale chips, and flies every where. Not coming back here again. The salsa was the only good thing too bad the chips tasted like they were sitting out since last month.
author: Tiger T.

description: This might not be a big deal with some customers but, I ordered a mushroom quesadilla with sour cream and guacamole (to go). They forgot to add the guacamole and sour cream. So I headed 2 miles back to have them correct my order. There were probably 2 customers ahead of me.  I told the staff they forgot to add the sour cream and guac and the lady told me I did not pay for it. I know I did because I come there once a week and order the same thing. She then told me there was sour cream in the quesadilla and I showed her there was not. She refused to add it. The staff at La Fonda were rude! I have been a loyal customer here for about a year but not any more.
author: Cup C.

description:
Apprently I go here 3 times a week now....

I only get the rice bean and cheese, no salsa...and its amazing!

Not the cheapest burrito, but its worth it.   Gotta love the salsa bar for pairing with the free chips...Im obsessed with the light green stuff.   

Super warm upstairs if you plan on enjoying your burrito on a cold day
author: Cassie B.

description:
I've been here at least a half a dozen times so I can tell you from my experience that it has slipped over time. This is a classic example of what happens when the quality of food a restaurant prepares and serves deteriorates. The food has gone from very good to nothing to write home about. 

Not too long ago I had dinner here and was disappointed all around. The food was just okay, the staff members were shouting and the radio was blaring. This doesn't add up to a nice dining experience. On my last visit, literally and figuratively, I realized while eating my burrito that it didn't taste like... anything.  

On the positive side of the ledger, on a sunny day the light pours into the restaurant, making the seats near the large open window warm and inviting. The sidewalk tables are pleasant, too.
author: Michael J.

description:
I've really tried to give La Fonda a chance over the course of the past year and a half, and it's just awful. The most bland mexican food you can ever get. I ordered a street taco, which was almost $3, and the tortilla was wet and slippery and kind of raw. Like they had just put it on the grill, or even a microwave, for literally 2 seconds. 

This store also plays 2 different radios at the same time, loudly, and is really anxiety inducing. The service is bad, $1 for refills. Over priced crappy bland food. I wish this neighborhood had a good mexican food restaurant. Gordos isn't really any better.
author: Catface G.

description: I live in the neighborhood and this is the best mexican place around, reallu nice, taty and fresh food,  good and fasr service. I don't know why is so underrated.  Loved it.
author: Amy S.

description: They've been around now for a while.  First, the place itself is tight.  And on a warmish day, it gets really hot inside.  I hope they make enough money to expand (or move to a little bigger space but stay in the neighborhood).  This time I opted for a taco al pastor, guacamole, and a cheese handmade corn quesadilla.  I've never even seen a taco al pastor so I can't say whether it was "correct" or not but it was very tasty, reminded me of the tacos we got down on the beach in Mexico, simple but tasty.  I could have put some of the salsas I took but I liked it as it was (don't need to scorch my tastebuds with hot sauce in order to eat it, was good as it was).  But it didn't look like the meat was sliced off one of those rotating meat skewers, looked like chopped pork.  I'm going to go back for more soon.  The guacamole was fine, lots of tomatoes in it which I'm not used to (seems like all the Mexican places are doing different things to "extend" their guacamole, some are chopping up lots of ciilantro and parsley, some are putting lots of onions and other stuff in there, once place overdid it with too much lemon) but we did eat it all.  And I loved the corn tortilla quesadiilas--nice taste and texture (better then the regular wheat ques you get at other taquerias).  Their fish tacos are just ok, I'll haul down to Rubio's when I have a fish taco jones (love their Mahi Mahi tacos)--but La Fonda's are about on a par with Pacific Catch over on 9th-Lincoln and not so expensive.  It is a different taste from your average taqueria, just wish the place were a bit bigger and didn't get so bleeding hot on warm days.  Oh, yea, and I don't care that they only give you a handful of chips, I don't come here to fill up on chips, I come for the real food.  I will need to attempt to get up earlier so I can taste their breakfast fare or else ask them if they serve breakfast all day long.  Oh, yea again, I trucked over to Church St. to try La Castillito's tacos al pastor and although they were good, I like La Fonda's a little bit better--less "sweet" (I'm not into sweet tasting foods).  I just wish they'd put shredded cabbage on it cause I love shredded cabbage.
author: Kai T.

description: I come here often usually over the top service but today by far is the worst service I've even gotten from this place. Who ever rang me up was rude as hell (I've never seen her here before). I won't be coming here during this time anymore.
author: Ocho B.

description:
Yes.

I've never had anything bad from here, seriously. Just thinking about this place makes me want to go so I'll be brief. I usually go with a burrito, they have a few self-serve salsas to choose from, and their prices are decent. There's a second floor too so seating isn't really a problem. Excellent. Okay, go!
author: Barrett I.

description:
One day a starving redhead - aka "Red" got off the N and scanned Ninth and Irving for possible eating options. 

Stomach growling, "Red" walked up to the entrance of La Fonda.

She went inside. 

Skimming the menu quickly, she decided she'd order the tofu burrito with extra guacomole. The clerk at the front smiled and nodded approvingly. 

In about 5 minutes the burrito was wrapped and glistening in foil. 

It was ready to roll.

"Red" grabbed the burrito and headed out. 

Before she had taken two steps she began to smell wafts of warmed rice and sniffed the silver burrito lump. She promised her stomach that they would be home soon, but her stomach had it's own agenda.

It grumbled. It tightened. And kept on nagging. "Come on....puh-lease... just one small bite." Despite attempts to ignore her badgering stomach, she couldn't.  She unwrapped a corner of the tightly bound bundle and took one little nibble.

It was delicious. Warm tofu in a sweet red sauce, wrapped in flavored rice, with cheese, guacomole and lettuce. Taste explosion. She folded down the tinfoil and put the burrito back in it's bag. But it kept on calling her name.

"Ohhhhhhhhhhh Reeeeeedddddddddddd. You know you want me. Come on now...just one little bite. Lil nibble never hurt no one."

Her stomach began to squirm at the incessant burrito taunting. But she just pulled her belt tighter and kept on walking. Burrito still in the bag. But the burrito taunts got louder and louder, as did her stomach, struggling to move beneath her tightened jeans.

She stopped and looked at the burrito hard. "Fine! Just one more bite"

The tortilla puckered in delight.

And she took one bite. Bigger than before. She could taste the melted cheese and it danced in her mouth. Her eyelashes fluttered and her stomach squealed in delight. "Oooooooo  just one more bite. Come on now...You can save the rest for America's Next Top Model tonight" It made sense. She took one slightly bigger bite - this time she could taste the guacamole. The burrito grinned. Red was his. All his. 

 
She'd only walked a block now, but already there was guacomole all over her face, the red sauce dribbled down her left cheek. People on the street stared at her in both disgust and bewilderemet. Who was this red-headed burrito possessed fiend?

But the foil covered burrito kept on working it's tofu voodoo..

As she neared the corner - she took one more huge bite - only to realize that she was chewing on hard aluminum. The metallic taste sent shivers down her spine.

La Fonda's tofu burrito was gone. 

The sky darkened, and clasping the empty bag in her hands - she felt ashamed yet relieved. 

The burrito was no more. 

But deep within the echoes of her gurgling stomach...she knew that her sordid burrito trysts with La Fonda had only just begun...

TO BE CONTINUED...

PLEASE NOTE -   La Fonda is no Papalote. It's no El Metate. But their tofu burrito can definitely still hold it's own in the burrito ring)
author: Jessica T.

description: Let me get straight to the point- NO CHEESE! Came here for a bite to eat and ordered enchiladas and a two tamales. The chicken enchiladas didn't even have any cheese in them or on them. I was expecting cheese because usually enchiladas are cheesy goodness but nope not here. Also the tamales we got were super dry. Basically, really unhappy with what I ordered.
author: Ranna K.

description: Really not much of a reason to go here when you have Gordo's close by and if you want a nice sit down restaurant, Nopalito. La Fonda has pretty mediocre food. Its pretty bland and just a lot of cheese and fat. The burrito also always gets soggy from the bean juice and grease and falls apart. The service is pretty bad, they're always rushing you, being dismissive and rude. The restaurant itself is pretty crummy, cramped and kind of dirty. There's just so many better places out there that are more impressive.
author: Dexter H.

description:
With this tough economy and diners being more selective about the value of eating out, you would expect restaurants to make an extraordinary effort to cater to the dwindling throng.  Many restaurants are offering coupons or other gimmicks to lure customers.  These restaurants are probably on the verge as really successful ones don't need to do this.   La Fonda offers coupons, but their attitude indicates indifference to its customers.

It is been awhile since I came here, probably since my first review which I gave it two stars.  Last night we decided to eat here again for two reasons.  First, we had some coupons to use and secondly we were in the neighborhood.

There were 3 persons working there, a female cashier, a female preparer, and a male in the back.  The cashier seemed very friendly and attentive. It wasn't very busy. It looked like they added additional items to their menu. The condiments were full and it seemed relatively clean.  However, they let the once beautiful oak floors turn grimy.  All of the polyurethane was worn out and the oak color was turning black.  It looked gross.

We ordered a super beef burrito ($8) and a chili relleno dinner ($9).  The portions were huge and we took them upstairs to eat.  I cut into my burrito and took a bite and it was cold!  The cook did not bother to heat it up, just slap it together, rolled it up and flopped it on the plate.  I don't mean it was lukewarm - it was cold.  I could not distinguish what was in the burrito - it looked like a bunch of mushy tasteless glop.   My companion said her dinner was "okay" as she is not very critical.  The chips that came with our meals were leathery and I nearly cracked my filling eating it. 

There was another Mexican restaurant near 6th/Irving that use to serve cold burritos also.  It has shrunk to a shell of its former self with much of its space occupied by a middle eastern restaurant.  La Fonda is heading in the same direction.

La Fonda has not taken any progressive steps to improve themselves and the quality of food has certainly gone downhill.  Maybe that are confident that their customers don't care about the slop they serve and feel they have a monopoly in the area.  Certainly, I don't want to go back here again, no matter how many coupons they offer.  If anyone can recommend a better place in the area, I'd like to know.  Maybe we should go back to the dreaded Chevy's again!
author: Robert J.

description:
Wow, Yelpers, thanks for the letdown.

Carne asada burrito w rice, guacamole, lettuce, and salsa for $8.49 and it was ASTOUNDINGLY small. No flavors stood out and I couldn't even taste the "spicy" salsa.

The only reason they don't get 1 star is the place was clean and the service was friendly. Color me disappointed.
author: Tobias P.

description:
La Fonda is not the best thing that has ever happened to me.

I'm always down for Mexican food but these dishes are a bit bland and there really isn't anything special about their menu. Just an average Mexican restaurant that serves what you would expect. But thankfully they have a salsa bar to spice up your meal. 

However, the restaurant is clean, brightly decorated and is a nice place to sit inside or outside on a nice sunny afternoon. It's also inexpensive with generous portions. 

La Fonda is alright. It's hard to love a place like this when there's an abundance of amazing Mexican restaurants all over the city.
author: Denise S.

description: Not just a greasy cuchara burrito shop. The seasonings and salsas have hints of regional flavor. Try the Azteca burrito!
author: Stephen S.

description:
Cochinita Burrito ALL DAY.


This ain't your average burrito spot. High Quality products and they have a dish with Bacon...what more do you need to know.

Skip Gordos because they are OVER RATED
author: Mike F.

description:
so I do think burritos here may be a step (or a half-step) above those from gordos, but gordos has got the better price. still need to try other items from the menu but yes, the burritos are pretty good. I've lived in a few different neighborhoods in the city (never the mission) and have always had trouble finding good Mexican food without having to trek to the mission to get it. glad this place is here. 

side note: there's some flavor tinting the tortilla chips that they throw in the bag with the burrito that I'm not feelin. don't like them at all.
author: Georgia W.

description:
My personal favorite Mexican in the Sunset. 

Their cochinita pibil is awesome, especially when served in their panuchos, which were something new to me. Take two small thick corn tortillas, add cochinita pibil, pickled onions, and a habanero sauce in between like it was a sandwich, and you've got a really tasty dish. Next time I go back, I'll ask for three of them and I'll be even happier than I was than when I ate the standard serviing of two.

The other dish I've had was a regular mole burrito, with pinto beans, rice, and hot sauce. Mole was dark and rich, and better than most mole I've had (and that's a lot), however I think I prefer L'Avenida's mole just a tiny bit more on account of it being a bit lighter and less rich.

Comparing L'Avenida to La Fonda on points other than the mole, I give L'Avenida points for being a hole in the wall, for the fact that you get better service when you can order in Spanish, which is always something I love as an indicator that you're about to eat really good food. Salsa is a toss up between the two with both being good in my book. Those points aside, La Fonda edges out L'Avenida by a hair in my book on account of the much bigger menu and the fact that I can actually fit my legs under the tables. 

But that said, I'll be happy eating at either and after just moving to the Sunset, I'm sure I'll be eating at one or the other basically every week.
author: Chris S.

description: La Fonda has probably the best Al Pastor I have ever had...it's a good hidden gem there. However I hope you like your service with a scowl! Literally the surliest Mexican ladies I have ever encountered....we found a coupon in the mail for this place and when I put it on the counter she literally did the deep sigh and rolled her eyes...hey lady don't put out coupons if you don't want people to use them! Rant ended. I haven't tried anything else here but the Al Pastor is legit.
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
I'm surprised I haven't written up about La Fonda...

So, basically this place is fairly good. Portions are just about right, and I love their burritos. I usually get their azeteca burritos with either pork or beef. Horchata is served fresh here as well. They might not have a lot of chips for you, but if you eat a lot, you can always get some more later.

They seem to be adding new items to their menus now. I just had a pork empanada, and it was GOOD. I'll definitely try their other stuff, since I've almost always had just a burrito. Great place, even if it's in the Sunset.
author: Clinton L.

description:
The decor is cute and friendly. 
It's down the street from my house and they open a lot later than most places around the Sunset.
It's not as authentic as the taquerias in the Mission but I love any place with a salsa bar! 
JALAPENO EATING CONTEST ANYONE?
Veggie burrito with no sour cream and no cheese!
Oh and if you're vegan, avoid the spinach tortilla, it has whey in it.
author: Justine L.

description: Saw the sign for barbacoa on saturday and sundays and followed my nose in. Rich and spicy, hunks of tender lamb. Slow cooked and succulent nestled in two corn tortillas with pickled onions and salsa. Excellent taco, well-priced at $3.50. Also tried the panucho, two crispy corn shells with barbacoa pibil, spicy pork, laid inbetween. Best panucho i've had in san francisco. Service was crisp and friendly and the restaurant appeared very clean. Huge menu offering a variety of meats and sauces. The chips are fresh and crispy and are offered along with three salsas, a green tomatillo, spicy roasted red and pico de gallo. Jicama  and cilantro are available at the salsa table as well. Follow your nose, fresh tasty mexican in the sunset.
author: Kelly K.

description: All of my shrimp had not been cleaned; the thin black line of poop was in each of them. Disgusting!!!
author: Sabrina S.

description:
As far as Mexican food in the Inner Sunset goes, this place isn't too bad. The great thing about La Fonda; they offer more then just burritos and tacos, so do yourself a favor and try their other items out. Give their Sopes, Chorizo, Chile Relleno, and Huarache's a try. They're tasty and filling. Another positive; you can have all the free salsa you want and don't have to go through that guilt of having to ask for more prepackaged salsa cups. 

La Fonda isn't as authentically tasting as it comes, but it will give you that fix if you can't make it to the mission. They used to have Posole during the weekends, and for some reason they stopped. Which is really upsetting considering that was my favorite item on their menu. 

They've also got really good Horchata and aqua frescas so do get some of those beverages when you eat there!
author: Junia I.

description:
After running in the park with my gigantic dog and normal sized boyfriend, we decided (the humans at least) that we wanted brunch.  But we wanted it now, we wanted to sit in the sun and we needed a place that wasn't ridiculously crazy so that the dog could chill out.  We also didn't want to walk or run back to our 'hood and get cleaned up.  We just wanted food now.

So, we were meandering up Irving and faced with the typical choices of bagel shop where we could eat and walk, the crepe place that's super crowded and coffee shops - which don't have full breakfasts, we happened upon la Fonda.  We've walked by plenty of times, but on this particular morning, the sun was just warm enough and there were open outdoor tables.  Perfect!

I sat down on a broken chair (they were all broken - I think from sun damage), but surprisingly it was fine.  My boyfriend went inside to order for us, while I settled in with the pooch.  He picked up huevos rancheros (his fave) and I got an egg scramble.  Both were fine.  Not exceptional or outstanding or bad for that matter, just fine.  It filled my belly, tasted fresh and allowed us a relaxing and quiet (except for all the people that stop to chat with and about the dog) meal.  

So, I haven't been for burritos, dinner, etc.  But to grab a quick bite without having to wait - this is a decent option.
author: Mac M.

description:
The super tacos are my favorite with a little mix-n-match on the meat.

They are pretty good about letting you get creative on your order, like mix-n-match the meat, or sub out items.

It can get a bit crowded at lunch and dinner, so go early.

My only complaint is that it is getting a little worn down from use and harsh cleaning solvents.  The paint around the place and on the tables is getting stickier with each visit.

Oh, and people with strollers...maybe you can leave them outside? Pretty please? One stroller in there and it's like a Coachella concert trying to get around the place.
author: Tristan D.

description:
So many choices
And tasty combinations
La Fondarrito
==========

I wish that I lived closer to La Fonda so I could go more often. They have so many different types of meats that all taste so good...

This is one of my (several) places of choice after a weekend jog in the park.  Viva La Fonda.
author: Jin D.

description:
Pro's:

- quick & friendly service
- accept credit/debit
- centrally located in the inner sunset
- open semi late

Con's

- food is bland and not very tasty
- meat in my burritos has always been dry
- just an average Mexican restaurant
- prices are a little higher than other comparable restaurants

If it wasn't for the food quality being low, I would come back because the place seems pretty clean and the ladies working behind the counter are always friendly.
author: R A.

description:
I debate over La Fonda or the Mexican restaurant on Irving when I am feeling a craving for a tasty burrito. La Fonda always wins!

+The food is totally on par with the price. Delicious salsa bar, chips! I have tried many a burrito, salad and the huevos rancheros. None have ever disappointed. I usually have left overs too because the portions are pretty large :)

+On a sunny day they open the windows and it is really awesome to sit inside.

YUM!
author: Jess T.

description:
I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised on my first visit to La Fonda. I have passed this place many times on my drives up and down Irving and not too long ago I decided to give it a shot. I was with my girlfriend and came in around 9:00 pm on a Sunday night.

The restaurant itself was very quaint, and it even had an upstairs area for dining. Although the downstairs (where the counter and "kitchen" is) was a bit cramped, the food that the two women made that night was really solid. I ordered a steak fajita burrito and my girlfriend ordered flautas. 

Our food was out within ten minutes (there was probably 3 or 4 other couples in there) and the portions that they gave were generous. Our meals combined were less than $20 including a drink and we both really enjoyed our food. The burrito I had was larger than I expected it would be, and my girlfriend's food filled up her entire plate. We were both full by the end of dinner. 

in addition to the food and overall good aesthetics of the restaurant, they had a small salsa bar at the end of the counter in which you could fill up a little cup full of any of the different salsas they offered. It was a nice touch to a restaurant that uses their limited space nicely.

Overall I would definitely recommend this place to anyone in the Sunset who is craving Mexican food. The people running the restaurant were friendly, the food was really good, and the price was right for the amount of food that we got. I will definitely be coming back to La Fonda's in the future.
author: Sean B.

description: Pretty good but not great. As others mentioned, Mexican places in this area are few and far between, so sometimes it just hits the spot. Staff could be more friendly.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I love burritos and La Fonda is my favorite local stop.  The hot salsa rocks and the service is usually warm and friendly.  

Also, if you like 80's music, they have a great mix that always has one or two surprises.
author: jon c.

description:
I've had the burritos at La Fonda's on a few occasions, although I am much more of a taco person.

They are average, maybe even moderately good. Don't expect a hugely memorable experience, but the prices are fairly decent and the food isn't bad.

Don't cross town to eat here, but if you are in the neighborhood, I wouldn't necessarily advise against it.

Plus 1 star for my being able to call this place "La Fowwwwwnda"
author: Sara D.

description:
Above average burrito (the world needs more mexican joints that serve tofu swimming in ranchero sauce)

+

Below average prices (less than $6)

=

Yay! I'm a fan.
author: Jason B.

description:
This is my Favorite restaurant in the city. I eat here maybe 3-5 times a week on average. Nothing beats the veggie burrito chips and salsa for $3.80 which is what i get about 95% of the time. The other 5 belongs to the chile relleno burrito which is a premium item at over $5.00, but it's perfect if you're in the mood for cheese. I would also recommend the rice pudding if that's your thing. 

The employees, the music, the brightly colored walls, and the natural light coming from the sunroof and the large window in the front all present a very cheerful atmosphere.

The only complaint I have about the place is that regardless of the fact that I'm in there almost daily and I"ve so rarely varied from my staple order for the past 2 years they still ask me what I want to order. Also, the ice dispenser breaks down every once in a while, not really a big deal though.
author: Zach K.

description:
I decided to test out the La Fonda, initially very suspicious of any Mexican restaurant outside of the Mission district. I am a fan of Balazo, "hey, what the heck?" 

When I came in, I was pleased to see the Latino staff, that was the first good sign. Also, the menu offered lots of Mexican specialties that are often left off most Mexican-American restaurants such as sopes and huaraches. As a vegetarian, one of the first things I notice is how well the restaurant caters to the non-flesh eaters. It looks like they had several burrito options, and one included this strange tomatoey tofu. The gracious attendant gave me a sample, which was for the best, because I would not have been happy had the tofu made its way into my burro. 

I went with the super veggie burrito and sope without meat. They were both tasty, standard Mexican fare. Pleasing to the taste buds, but nothing to get excited about. I think next time I have the hankering for Mexican food, I will stick with the places I know to be delicious (Pancho Villa, Balazo, Picante, and anything in Fruitvale).
author: Daniel M.

description: Don't ever come here!!! I'm trying to save everyone from experiencing what happened to me. I had the 'Azteca Nachos' last night for dinner. 30 minutes after my stomach starts hurting. About two hours later, at home, it gets gradually worse to the point that I'm just laying on my bed clutching my side. Later on in the night I finally just puked, it was all the nachos and that crap swimming in my toilet. Soon as I puke I feel instantly better. Don't ever go here. It's horrible.
author: Luis R.

description:
When I lived in the Sunset this was the taqueria I would go to every week.  Yup, EVERY week.  For an entire year.  And NEVER got sick of it!

They offer authentic Mexican food and it's very obvious once you get a bite of it.  The owner, when I met him over a year ago, told me that he was from Mexico and he took pride in the making of every entree.  I was sooo happy to have a really good taqueria in the neighborhood it was hard to not go there every week.  Especially for their salsa, incredibly fresh and with wonderful seasoning.  

My favorites are their super veggie burrito and their cheese enchilladas.  Abso-f**n-lute-ly delicious!
author: Swetha G.

description: Horrible place. It was the blandest burrito I have ever eaten. The quesadilla was nothing more than greasy oil. Avoid at all costs.
author: D V.

description: I am writing a review for this mexican restaurant as I want them to know their burritos are great! and the drinks esp the lemonade is mouth watering. The ladies are nice. The only thing I would mention to them is their space is a little crowded which does not give  you a lot of privacy if you are with someone even by yourself:)
author: Rup B.

description:
I just had a mushroom empenada from here and it was the best thing I've ever had from this restaurant! Delicious - do try!!

I've had their nachos, veggie super burrito, tacos - the standard, which are pretty standard taste wise too. But the empenadas blow everything else out of the water!
author: Twinstar G.

description:
My best friend and I were spending the day near Golden Gate Park and decided to pick a random joint to grab some dinner. We ended up at La Fonda. Let's just get to the review.

The Good:

The food was decent and they had a fairly nice selection. The restaurant, while small, was kept up well. I had the shrimp and barbacoa tacos and some nachos. The barbacoa was nice but the shrimp and nachos were sub-par. 

The Bad:

THE STAFF! Holy crap. The lady taking our order was rude and didn't appear to be listening half of the time. I think we had to repeat my friend's order twice. Their way of serving food is poorly thought out as well. They just hand you a tray and don't tell you that they will just call out your dish so that you can walk back up to pick it up. Kinda confusing but okay. Also, no free refills. REALLY!? Very rarely do you find a place that will charge for refills anymore and to me, that's just a joke. They lost a star solely on that little tidbit. 

Conclusion:

Normally I would give this place another shot! Occasionally you get a bad dish or you have to go a few times to find the real gems at a restaurant, but this place wont get that opportunity. Unless they have a serious talk with their staff and get with the times on their drink policies (which, in my mind, is just a form of fleecing), you wont see me back there.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
the yelp-generated message next to the two stars i give this place sum up my feelings perfectly: meh, i've experienced better.

I love Mexican food, and I love it spicy. I used to work near La Fonda and my coworkers raved about it, but aside from the size of the burritos (they are huge!) I found it to be nothing special. The burrito itself didn't have much flavor, and while i of course utilized the salsa bar, I didn't find it to help all that much.  and what mexican restaurant doesn't provide cholula/tapatio?! 

Overall: I've definitely had way better, and paid much less. i'd go again if i absolutely craved mexican food and this was the ONLY option
author: Laura C.

description: If they can't get the rice and beans right, what's the use.horrible, just Filler, No Pop, No Wow.
author: Dan B.

description:
I like to go here because it's close and the food is pretty good. The prices aren't terribly high, but  a bit higher than what I would like to pay for Mexican food that, to me, isn't anything special. 

We usually get take out here and when you order, it's not like Gordo's where you say what you want and they make it on the spot. They write it all down and then make it. 

The ambiance is nice though. You have the downstairs and upstairs to eat and on a sunny day, i recommend sitting right next to their window. It makes you feel very warm and joyful eating by the window with a few of your close friends and family. 

They actually have quite a variety on their menu. It includes burritos, tacos, nachos, sandwiches, plates, etc. I usually get their burritos are the portions are pretty big. If you finish one regular burrito you'll be stuffed. There's a good variety of meats, but the meats aren't anything special. I also thing their burritos are a bit dry, where Gordo's is juicier. For good burritos though, you'll probably have to go to the mission. A good thing about La Fonda is that they usually give you a complimentary bad of tortilla chips and they have a salsa bar where you pick your own salsa. I don't recommend that dark red one though. 

I'd check this place out if you wanted to try a Mexican restaurant with some variety in their menus and want a nice pleasant setting to set in while eating.
author: robin w.

description:
Updated:

Still one of the only local taquerias and I'm kind of stuck here. I really HATE the way they take their orders and more than once have had problems both with their accuracy and with mixing them up.

I get it...prices have increased...I get it...I get it...reminding me of that every time isn't changing whether I order or not. I'm already there, you had me at "burrito." However, you are now becoming VERY expensive, not just expensive. And no need to keep telling me that you can't print a simple piece of paper with your menu on it...I'll just crane my neck, squinting and trying to figure out your menu with my guests while you stare at me.

And for that, you are losing my business. I will go out of my way to Zapata at this point.

==

It's local, and they give me coupons. It's expensive and inconsistent with portion sizes.

I go here frequently, typically just getting a taco or burrito. Occasionally I go with the family or a group of friends.

The way they take their orders is different than the other places because they write each order down on a separate slip of paper. If I order one or two items, no problem. Any time I order more than 4, there's ALWAYS at least one crossed-up item. Like cheese put on the no-cheese thing, or spicy versus mild...so on. It's damn annoying and I usually order a couple of things at a time just to avoid this.

I'll keep going back for one-off stuff. MUCH better than the place around the corner.
author: Scot B.

description:
I will Yelp this in Haiku:

Had a burrito
Chorizo with salsa bar
Good-bye to Gordo's
author: Tash T.

description:
OK! Don't tell the burrito, the quesadilla and the nachos, but I've found a new love - TACOS!

Lately, I've been heading here regularly, especially:
1. After my runs to get a meal that has a fair share of proteins, fiber and of course, carbs
2. After my mind decides it does not want to cook or eat home made food anymore 
3. After a hangover... or two... or three.. eh! it WAS Pride, mmm kay! 
4. With $5 in my pocket, I want a meal fit for a queen... king, I mean!

And it's tacos all the way, baby!
1. Regular Taco ($2.30) is as simple as it sounds. Taco with your choice of meat served with onions, cilantro (yum!) and salsa. Simple and tasty and not greasy or creamy at all
2. Super Taco ($3.60) is an amped up version of the regular taco served with sour cream, guacamole and shredded cabbage. Mind you, it WILL get messy! But you will be filled with just one.
3. Azteca Taco ($3.05) is again simple with grilled pork and grilled onions. More on the spicy side and little bit more oily than its brothers above.
4. Vegetarian Taco ($2.80) is all of the above minus the chicken, the pig or the cow.

And not to put the burrito down completely! Their ham and scrambled egg burrito is still great anytime of the day. Simple, filling, tasty, warm and filled with the goodness of protein and carbs.

... and for my next book... the secret affair of lazy, hungover super-athletes with tacos!
author: Amit S.

description:
At first I was not impressed with this place, but as in baseball it's the three strikes method.... and this place survived on strike two.

I have been there several times in the last month or two and while the burritos are not as good as Gordo's, I will say the panuchos and empanadas are quite impressive.  They do take a nice smattering of your own hand on the salt front, but otherwise they are spot on.  The pickled onions are also spiked with habeneros so be aware if you do not like heat...

All in all i seem to like this place more each and every time i go
author: frizzle-fry e.

description: Another good taqueria in the Inner Sunset. Everything I've eaten here is good, and the staff are always very polite and friendly. Tacos, burritos, quesadilla are all delicious, and the best item is available on weekends: "Barbacoa" - Barbecue lamb! The dinner plate comes with tortillas, rice, and a bowl of really good soup. Top of the line salsa!
author: James P.

description:
For Inner Sunset mexican food, these guys are the best of the three in the area. 

There's L'avenida a block down, and Gordo's around the corner on 9th. 

L'avenida used to be my favorite because it was easy to hop off the street car and easy to hop back on on my way home. But it seems that Lavash took over their old space and now L'avenida is really small and the quality of their meat has gone down hill. Gordo's has never been a favorite of mine, they just slop their burritos together in front of you with few choices for ingredients
author: Leo V.

description: A very bland chicken burrito indeed.  Also quite soggy.  Not sure how this place has so many stars.
author: Audrey K.

description:
My boyfriend and I both had the Azteca Burrito with Chicken Mole.  They were filling and delicious.  We were sold.  

BUT... Cut to 4 hours later.  I was woken up in the middle of the night by terrible (we're talking TERRIBLE) acid reflux.  My stomach was killing me, my throat was burning, and I couldn't go back to sleep until several hours later when the pain subsided.  Keep in mind, my stomach is made out of steel.  I rarely ever experience heartburn or acid reflux.  The only time I have stomach aches like that is when I have a few too many whiskey sours (it happens.). 

Anyway, I'm going to give La Fonda another try, albeit I'm terrified.  Next time I'm going to go with something less intense.  Maybe a sope, or something.  

The final verdict:  avoid Azteca burritos, but don't avoid La Fonda altogether.
author: Nina B.

description: Food is really good but the women who work up front are not friendly at all. I'm a regular there and I've never seen them crack a smile...always makes me feel uncomfortable. Otherwise food is always fantastic.
author: S C.

description: I really like their Torta Milanese from their special's menu. The beef is tender and breaded, sooo tasty.  Hot chips and  fresh salsa are included (I like the salsa verde). Great value choice.
author: Akshay K.

description:
Ordered torta, carne asada. It's was good.

I've been there a few times and order the same thing however I gave it this rating because I have noticed that the place is dirty and it always looks like this. The servers are ambivalent- that with the grimy feel haven't given me a reason to want to go back.
author: Marisa E.

description: One star because I like the food. No more stars because 90% of the times I've been here the staff have been very rude. So rude, in fact, that I am writing this review. And I never write reviews. I am a kind and non-malicious person but the service today was just over the top nasty. They wouldn't even give me a bag for my burrito...wtf? I'll be getting burritos from gordos down the street from now on.
author: Emily C.

description:
Really good burritos. Like super good. They were plump (that's what she said). Filled with meat (haha that's what she said, sorry I'm on a roll) and rice and beans. 

It's a clean place with seating. The portions are huge. And you can't beat the chips and salsa. 

I want to go back and try the Chicken Mole.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Classic comfort food!  Having lived in the Sunset for over a year, I found myself frequenting this joint quite often. This was my first taqueria experience in the city and although it may not be 100% authentic, it certainly is delicious. Maybe I'm just a tad biased, but I really do love it and it is one of my favorite places to eat. It's a great place to get a good quality meal for just a few bucks. I find it pleasant to sit upstairs when it's cold and rainy outside (as you may have learned in 2nd grade science class, heat rises) - It sure does make for a cozy meal. The veggie burrito is my favorite thing on the menu...fancy that. I have also had the torta and a mushroom quesadilla, which were both equally pleasing. I have been satisfied with just about everything I have ordered here. Unfortunately since I have moved to Oakland, I haven't been in as much, but whenever I find myself in the Sunset and I have the chance, you better believe I am there eating. 

Keep your eye open because they have a coupon in the monthly  Value-Paks that go out: Buy one burrito and a drink, get a 2nd burrito of equal or lesser value free. Sweet!
author: Amber Y.

description: Cochinita Pibil takes like 4 hrs of cooking time, plus the prep, plus the shopping (most safeways dont carry fresh banana leaves).  So when i order it its kind of like buying time. After trying it at LF, i'm forced to say that those are 4 hours of my life i wish i spent slowly roasting a perfectly seasoned cut of pork in a banana leaf, instead of buying them for eleven sixty three, or whatever it is, more than a mile away from Mission. One of those cases where you really get what you paid for :( Also arguably the coolest thing about this place is the 2nd level, but it seemed like all the steam from the kitchen and some weird funky smells just drifted up and congregated up there (i mean i was pretty normal at ground level, but upstairs was hot and kinda stinky)
author: Oleg H.

description: I applaud La Fonda for trying to create a restaurant with cheap Mexican menu that has more style. It's clean and not sloppy. It's located on Irving. I generally like their burritos because I can eat it without gagging. The menu is simple.
author: Denise C.

description: La Fonda makes some good beans and rice. That's about all we usually eat there so I cannot speak for the meat dishes. The people who work there are really nice.
author: Flora O.

description: I've never had a bad meal at La Fonda.  Great Mole, lovely Cochinita Pibil, Fresh Chips, and the Lamb!  It seems that recently (or maybe not so recently) they began serving lamb on the weekends - have it on a simple taco without the accessories for it is marvelous.
author: A B.

description: Quick, tasty food, and very affordable. For the price, it is hearty food with fresh ingredients served by enthusiastic Latin people. The food may not be the best, neither going for the most authentic crown. However the peppy colors on the walls, the smiling Latin family like staff behind the counter, and their earnest effort in serving you warm enchiladas or empanadas with horchata makes me go there again and again.
author: Parin K.

description: I had always passed this place but never felt compelled to try it. But since I had my doggie with me last night and couldn't bring him into a normal restaurant, we decided to eat here b/c they have tables out front. My friend got us 2 super tacos- Grilled Chicken and Chicken Mole. Both were good, but the Mole one was definitely better. It tasted like chocolate chicken yummy! There isn't anything exciting about the food here, but it's pretty cheap and does it's job by feeding you. But mainly, the outdoor tables in front are a huge perk!
author: Sonya D.

description: It's been a while since I've eaten here, and since I was in the neighborhood I stopped by for dinner last night.  I don't think I've hade a less tasty meal anywhere else in San Francisco. It wasn't gross, it's just nearly devoid of flavor and moisture.
author: Daniel H.

description:
This place is alright, def not memorable. The burrito is hella average. There is no legitamate salsa to speak of in this venue, and the super burrito is just eh with out. All the stars are for the employees. Real sweet people. 

I remember walking by and they were closing and they still let me order last minute  , with a smile. Grateful for customers...what a concept!

So if you need to hit a burrito, this is the 2nd best choice. ( The other is across the street, can't remember the name). 

Hit a different neighborhood altogether if you are looking for dece mexican food.
author: Taj A.

description:
As far as the inner sunset goes, I think this is one of the better Mexican places in the area.  The other is Gordo's but that's another block away and thus another 90 seconds of walking before getting my burrito.  And when I have a burrito craving, 90 seconds is an eternity.  They have a good selection of meat and beans, and they just seem cleaner and less lardy than other burrito joints (which I know for many burrito aficionados may be a con.. but I'm trying to watch my figure here).  

P.S. the burrito azteca is good for two meals and it's covered with the enchilada sauce which i love.
author: William S.

description: I come here a lot. I'm partial to the quesadilla with chorizo, the hot red salsa, and green tomatillo salsa. And the always friendly staff. Decent burritos and nachos also. I feel like some things are much better on the menu than others; the mole chicken is good, but it's always hard for me to finish. They give you a lot of options for your choice of meat, if you're a met eater. I can't even remember them all, but I think it's steak, chorizo, grilled chicken, mole chicken, carnitas, and more.
author: Ken L.

description:
A-okay.  That's about the quickest summary I can give you about this sometimes-really-delicious, sometimes disappointing Mexican joint.  

So I'll just start out with the Good: Veggie Options & Portions.  The Tofu Ranchero just hits The Spot (sometimes). The mix of rice, tofu, refried beans and salsa just makes the stomach sing. Surprisingly delicious (when they choose to make it right).  The portions are pretty big--you'll probably have enough left over for a snack later on that night.   

The Bad: Service, Salsa Bar, Food. You just never know what to expect. The cashiers either greet you like you're the one they've been waiting for all their lives or like you're the thing the cat dragged in. The Salsa Bar is okay, but really, what would I know?  I've avoided it since I saw people using their bare hands to scoop out salsa. The Food is just inconsistent.  It can be the best thing you've eaten since forever or the most disappointing fare you've put 10 bucks down for in awhile.  

The Ugly:  Okay... this would be exaggerating.  Nothing is that bad here, but it definitely rounds out the review, don't you think?

All in all, come here with your expectations low and you'll be just fine. Heck, who knows, you might just be stopping by on a good day.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Currently my favorite place to get a burrito.

(This review is strictly on a burrito bias)

Here are the reasons why:
1. I live in Inner Sunset, so this is the perfect burrito pit stop for me on the way to my house.
2. They always have coupons in the neighborhood Valpak offering X amount of $ off any single item, and even buy one burrito get the second one free.
3. Most importantly, the burritos taste amazing, the meat is well seasoned and grilled in front of you, also the combination of the ingredients is always perfect, the right amount of rice, beans meat, cheese and salsa.
4. Salsa bar, I think there are five different salsas to pick from, and I still can't decide on a favorite.
5. Free chips with all orders.
6. Horchata is perfect, not too sweet but enough flavor to devour a cup in 3 mins.

I have tried several of their burritos, including the vegetarian burrito, theaztec wet burrito, and my favorite just the regular burrito with spicy salsa.
The ladies who work there are always smiley and are friendly.

Overall, if you are looking for a local burrito spot in the Sunset this is the one!  It blows Gordo's out of the water.
author: Jaclyn O.

description:
The food is nothing to write Guadalajara about.  Maybe Tijuana.  But definitely not Guadalajara.

But what they lack in salt and flavor, they make up in the best Salsa Verde this side of San Diego and stupid Marina girls doing the walk of shame.  

Plus, all the pickled Jalapenos you can eat.  And if you know me at all,  then you know there are two things I love - pickles and stupid Marina girls doing the walk of shame.

I actually don't love stupid Marina girls doing the walk of shame and was about 10 seconds from turning around and sticking a fork through her yellow Steve Madden leather moccasins.

Her "bro-date" was already hitting the brew at 10am, as she droned on about how "gross" and "bad for you" cheese was.

That's when I took a big bite of my burrito, and let the cheese sort of hang out of my mouth for a minute as I winked at him.  He liked it.

Come to the dark side, popped collar boy.  Come to the dark side.

The girls might be a little bigger, but they clean their plates, if you know what I mean.

And I am almost positive you have no idea.
author: Rachel G.

description: It's not authentic Mexican food, but it will do the job of satisfying hunger or an immediate Mexican food craving. They have a lot of vegetarian options, which I like.
author: Gloria B.

description:
It took me a few visits to get into the rhythm of La Fonda.

For example - if you want cheese on your burrito, you have to buy a super burrito - you can't add cheese a la carte.  And if cheese is all you want - you have to have them subtract out everything else, which tends to freak them out.

But heck, it's their rule not mine.

Fortunately the food's good.   Not great but good.

I agree with others - the grilled chicken burrito is their best. 

I wish there was a 3.5 on Yelp... because La Fonda is better than a 3 - but not yet a 4.
author: Rick C.

description:
Decent veggie burrito.  Their menu had a lot of other interesting items that I might go back for (Mexican sandwiches, ect).

Service was A-OK.  

I appreciate the eco-friendly utensils.
author: Don B.

description:
people are retarded when they think that its a "burrito joint". Somehow all americans think that Mexican food is all burritos. Its not. 

In Mexico, we dont even have burritos... anywhere. A burrito is like a made up American thing. Just like chilli and all those other nasty fake mexican meals. So calling this place "inauthentic" or a "burrito joint" is ignorant and stupid.

As a Mexican i can actually say that this place is as authentic as it can get in the US. The sopes are amazing, the huaraches are delicious and the salsas actually taste like something. Of course they make them a little light tasting but thats only because Americans cant handle the spicyness and complain too much.

The molletes are done different then they are done in mexico but still, they are incredibly delicious. Their veggies are fresh and their aguas frescas taste home made and not like canned juices.

Gordos is a mexican fast food place that scores a 1 compared to la fonda. which BTW. its LAH PHONe DAH. not law fawnduh. it doesnt even SOUND like lawfawnduh. 

of course its hard to find real mexican food here cuz well.. there isnt. you want mexican food. real mexican food? GO TO MEXICO. no jodas.

this place is amazing and it has become my usual "after the doctor visit" food place. 

que pinche burrito joint ni que pinche burrito joint. pinches pendejos. FTP.
author: Bella G.

description:
Lafawnduh?

Sit outside at one of the two tables if the weather's sunny.

If you're trying to *not* get fat, order the salmon taco because it's hella small and not fried.  Also had a lime aquas fresacas and it was light & refreshing.  I had no hangover, but would have guzzled a few if I'd had one.

Date had a super burrito.  It kept him full from 12noon until now (9:15pm) but it wasn't the best burrito ever.  It kind of was just like, a burrito, ya know?

Have you ever been to a burrito place and watched someone load up on the salsa minicups con lids?  Like, load up on an abnormal amount of salsa?  Lafawnduh is totally onto this.  They keep their lids out but the cups are behind the counter for loss prevention.
author: Megan G.

description:
Get the Azteca Burrito!  Seriously, just do it.  It's amazing!!!  The sauce is a perfect combination of sweet and flavorful.  Plus, It's piled high with guacamole,  melted cheese and sour cream.  How do you go wrong with that?!  

I made the mistake of getting the super pollo burrito and although it was delicious, I ended up scooping up all the cheesy & saucy goodness from my bf's Azteca plate and piling it atop of my burrito.  This was by far the best burrito I've ever had (aka stolen bites of).  And believe me, I've eaten a lot of burritos.

Right off the N Judah line and within 2 blocks of GG Park, the location is perfect.  The restaurant itself was clean and colorful and had plenty of room with an upstairs section.

Carne Asada Azteca burrito, I'm coming back for YOU!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Great burritos, and authentic mexican food
service cholarific, shitty and rude - these ladies never smile
Gordo's much better
author: Pug P.

description: This place is good, but not great. Its good for a casual breakfast or lunch if your looking for some decent Americanized Mexican food this is definitely the place. I got the Fajita Quesadilla with steak which I did enjoyed but the Horchata I ordered was way too sweet but the ambiance is nice. I guess my big thing with this place was there was no one thing that stood out, that set it apart from all the other Mexican places. Maybe only that it was the best Mexican place around that area other than Gordos. I'll definitely come back just to try some other food and give this place a chance to raise in my ratings.
author: Anna B.

description:
When I'm in the mood for some Mexican during lunch time, I head on over to La Fonda (Lawfawnduh...She's uh... she's got sandy blonde hair. She's uh... pretty good looking face, but I'm just getting really... just kinda TO'd because... I mean she hasn't even sent me a full body shot yet.)

They offer really large portions which can be great for sharing (when you don't feel like heading back to work in a food induced coma).  Can't go wrong with the nachos or the burritos.  Their chips and salsa are also surprisingly good!
author: Christy L.

description:
Lo Siento La Fonda....La Comida es no bueno.  

1. Food was bland, no spices, no flavor. "Spanish rice" tasted like white rice and i had to load it up with salt.  

2. The lady said there were 4 tortillas in the box.  There was one. And it was so big I could have sewed it into a flour corset.  What good does this do for fajita tacos? 

3. I ordered it for takeout. There was no napkins, no plastic silverware, nada. 

4. Since there is no online menu, they will tell you on the phone that the fajitas come with guacamole and sour cream. Let me clarify: It comes with one ounce of guacamole and once ounce of watery substance that may imitate sour cream.
author: Courtney M.

description:
I love this place! Tasty everything, super friendly service, nice restaurant with sidewalk tables and upstairs people watching tables. The only thing you have to watch out for is the huge portions. Oh and you probably won't be able to get a big crowd in here, it's a pretty small place.

To set your expectations: this is a pickup counter place. No waiters.
author: Andrew M.

description: Your go to place for a quick and cheap burrito. Order, pay, and your burrito is pretty much ready! I had a chicken burrito with black beans on a spinach wrap (loved that I got a choice for the wrap). Your order comes with a bag of chips and there is a salsa bar for your choice of salsa. In and out in a jiffy, but you get what you pay for. I felt the burrito was A-okay at most. Service was definitely fast and efficient if you are on a time crunch.
author: Tracy T.

description: Love La Fonda! Great selection of fresh authentic dishes. I love that you can choose from various types of beans, chicken, and other condiments, which means you can be as healthy or indulgent as you would like! Super fast service. Always great when you have a craving for Mexican food! My only suggestion would be to add margaritas to their menu, in addition to their selection of beer and wine. Oh, and gotta love the salsa bar...who doesn't love a good salsa bar?
author: Bridget B.

description:
I was craving mexican food the other day. It is my favorite! I didn't want to travel far from my house and had walked by this place often in the mornings to get coffee. So I headed out my door and walked the 6 blocks. 
When I walked in I realized it was not my first time eating here. I ate here years ago with an old friend. I remember sitting upstairs and thinking what a cool neighborhood.... now i live here.... odd side note... no back to the review. 
I kept it simple. I got a chicken burrito. Even better they had an option for a whole wheat tortilla. The burrito was A-OK!! not the best but certainly not a disappointment. I saw someone next to me eating eggs, black beans and rice. Next time i think I will try that.
author: Wes P.

description:
The first two times I went here I was hungover and craving salt and grease. So I loved their breakfast items. Since then, I've come to realize that a LOT of their food is over salted. The breakfast has some potential, but I'm not sold on the rest of the menu. I had a decent veggie burrito, nothing special, but decent. I also had a chicken burrito and about 2/3 of the chicken was inedible. Waaaay too fatty and poorly cut and cooked. Tried the chicken again and the same thing. Their salsa is good though...

There's not much for Mexican in the Inner Sunset, but I'd say try something else.
author: Morgan A.

description:
When I moved to San Francisco, the foggy side of the city, I thought my days of having a great neighborhood taqueria nearby were gone. To my surprise, the Inner Sunset has La Fonda!

Everything I've had here is good -- flavorful and fresh. I am currently infatuated with their sopes...not the greasy, dense cakes you find everywhere else, but fresh, fluffy, corn-flavorful cakes that complement the savory meat topping of your choice.

There's room to sit and comfortably enjoy your food and best of all, everyone who works here is so friendly and nice, reflecting the sunny decor!
author: Moni K.

description: I love this place for it's good basic Mexican dishes, friendly service, cheerful setting, and good prices. Plus, we can walk there. With too many disappointing Mexican-type places (sorry Eldos) in the neighborhood, La Fonda is a respite delight.
author: Sunset G.

description:
I was born in San Francisco and apart from a few years in Europe and college in the five and dime and North Carolina I've lived here most of my life and most of that time, apart from a year or so in the Mission and a year or so in the Haight, has been spent in the Inner Sunset or close by. 

I don't say that to start one of those lame native vs. newcomer arguments, I know plenty of natives who got the hell out of SF the first chance they got  and never looked back and plenty of people who have moved here and made SF their home. I just want to give a little background when I make this statement: Between surly service and bad food, Gordo Taqueria, to paraphrase Bart Simpson, manages to both suck and blow.

Fortunately for those of us who dwell in the IS there is La Fonda. Sarang D. mentioned the alambre and I must concur by all means try the alambre, motherfuckers. Carne asada, cheese and, wait for it, BACON! All in one magical, delicious, peta-nightmare of a dish. Great tacos too, I prefer the al pastor.  They even have a good tofu burrito (so I've been told by a veggie friend, I wouldn't eat tofu with Nelson W's mouth!). The people behind the counter are friendly as well.
author: Philip G.

description: Blah .... I may be spoiled by mission taquerias or my (Mexican)  Sis in law great  cooking , however, this is not good mex food, I mean ,is good if you are really hungry, but is not some place you crave....sorry
author: Karen P.

description:
I feel like these days, bacon has a bad rep. I blame this on the North Beach dieters, Pilates loons, and health club nincompoops around the world. It's a little known fact that bacon is the greatest and most delicious meat in the universe. 

The number one reason for its greatness is its versatility. You can have 2 strips of crispy bacon with your eggs in the morning, chopped up in a nice albeit womanly salad, wrapped around a scallop and eaten while on ecstasy, or, the way La Fonda does it--layed across onions, peppers, and meat, and wrapped in a flour tortilla--the wonder that is "The Alambre". 

If you question the authenticity of this dish, then you my friend, have obviously never been to Mexico, where they kill and eat pigs on a daily basis and have no running water or electricity. I believe the main character in Desperado, the cinematic authority on Mexico, ate an Alambre whilst killing, playing guitar, and talking to Steve Buscemi. But, I digress. La Fonda is the go-to spot in the Sunset for hearty Mexican food. Just ask the guy from Desperado.
author: Steven H.

description:
My top two reasons I am glad that I stopped being a vegetarian:
1. bacon (duh hickey)
2. The grilled chicken burrito at La Fonda
 
I usually think chicken is the most boring of meats, but not the char grilled chicken from La Fonda. I also have some lingering fears from being a vegetarian that I am going to bite into some unidentified meaty object when eating something that has a lot of chopped up stuff inside, but I have never had that traumatic experience with La Fonda. They also have great chips and some of the best salsa which is my number one requirement for any taqueria or Mexican restaurant for that matter. Thumbs up kiddos!
author: Carly S.

description:
Went with a group of women who recommended the place. Our server was rude and had the personality of a flea. There was no substitution for the ground beef in the tostada even though we were willing to pay extra for the Carne Asada (steak). I had the chicken tostada and had diarrhea for a week after. 
I would never return nor recommend to anyone!!!
author: Gail W.

description:
After years of being duly unimpressed with both Gordo's and L'Avenida, I am very happy to have La Fonda in the neighborhood.  

First and foremost, the food is pretty good.  The meats are moist and flavorful, they don't skimp on the portions and everything tastes really fresh.  Other reasons for celebration: thick crunchy chips, tasty salsa bar, friendly staff, reasonable prices and a clean well-lit space.

My usual order: A refreshing strawberry agua fresca and a super taco con carnitas, SPICY!
author: Emily L.

description:
What? I haven't reviewed La Fonda yet?? Incredible!

I really only have one thing to mention; Tofu Ranchero. Get it in a burrito, or in a Flour Tostada (aka a taco salad), or on some Sopes... so tomatoey and delicious!

The staff at this restaurant are super nice, and very accommodating to special requests and substitutions, and despite the recent price increase, I think I get more for my money here than at other spots in the neighborhood.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Just moved to the Sunset, trying to explore burritos around my new hood.  
Damn what a letdown.  I ordered a carne asada super burrito and it was in the 8 dollar range already so immediate I'm thinking this better be good.  

I see them cooking my meat on the grill and I think to myself "that can't be my portion of carne, that's a kids size portion."  There is nothing super about the burrito.  LAME.  PLAIN.  And they are ripping you off with their SUPER SMALL portions of mean.  

I paid attention to them cooking after I noticed my order, and all the meat portions are extremely small.  I said something to the cashier who was nice and she just asked me of I wanted extra meat.  I didn't ask if she was going to charge me, I guess if she was going to give it to me free this place would have gotten 3 stars, but I doubt that, given that their were 10 people in line behind me and I'm sure they would all ask for the same thing.  I just said no.  No mo biznezz from me!

This place pisses me off and I've only been here once.  Unfortunately I can't recommend a better place in the area ATM, but I was definitely LET DOWN here.

Oh and to the people who gave this place glowing reviews, lay off the pot/booze and you'll get your tastebuds back.
author: jack s.

description:
Best place for Mexican food in the inner sunset.  No big accomplishment, but worthwhile nevertheless.  The chorizo and scrambled egg breakfast burrito is among the best I've had -- ideal to placate a hangover or just get your day started.  The portion is enough to satisfy your hunger but not so big that it'll put you out.  The standard burritos are also solid, with a large selection of meats to choose from.

I'm not as enthusiastic about their chilaquiles, as they're prepared in a runny style.  I much prefer the way Papalote makes chilaquiles -- more dense, melted cheese, pico de gallo on the side.
author: Leon R.

description: One star because the food is actually quite good.  Negative five stars for service.  Never returning.  I ordered an Azteca burrito and didn't realize that it would come in a box due to the sauce on top (call me an idiot, but at least I'm honest).  I asked the ladies working there twice, VERY nicely, if it was the Azteca... and received an impatient "yes" followed by a "chingas!" to the other lady.  At first I thought it was a racist remark given that I'm Asian, but I couldn't yell back since I didn't know what it meant.  Looked it up when I got home... Obviously I won't be returning because I shouldn't have to be cursed at when clarifying that I got the right food and not stealing somebody else's.  Too bad, because it was good enough to frequent a couple times a year.  On second thought, not a big loss.
author: Rob L.

description: OK food. I DO NOT recommend bringing a stroller here. It's too small and you will need some help carrying it up the steep stairs if you choose to eat there. Bathroom is strangly located by the cook area and the sink is not even inside the bathroom! If your a single dude trying to grab some quick Mexican food this is for you, if your a family with a baby this is NOT for you. You will become flustered fast!
author: Trish B.

description:
Santa Mara, Madre de Dios, ruega por nosotros pecadores, ahora y en la hora de nuestra muerte!!!

SNAP!
wow I think I was just speaking in tongue there.. excuse me phew...I'm ok,  just think I had a religious experience at La Fonda after eating a burrito.  Am I in the Sunset district? What is going on here?  
El Senor es contigo.
author: G L.

description: The first time I went in the middle of the afternoon, I got a steak burrito and some other things for the family. My baby and I both gobbled the burrito down--almost fighting for it! But the tamale dinner was just average--the pork better than the chicken, I think--but don't waste your appetite. Another visit I got some tacos for the family. The tacos are ok, but way too simple. I ordered some other steak-type taco, and it was essentially just meat and corn tortilla. (Anyway, nothing beats a La Taqueria taco!). When I asked the woman at the counter questions about the taco and the menu, she was short and pretty rude. There was still a good half hour or more until closing when I left, and maybe she had a long day, but I don't think that should be a reason for her rudeness.  I wouldn't return even for the free salsa.
author: Cara K.

description: I've been coming to this place on and off for years and unfortunately the quality has gone downhill recently. This is the the 3rd or 4th time where I've gotten a super burrito from this place that consisted almost entirely of beans and rice. I'm not sure if they are trying to save money or what but its been enough to inspire me to write a review.. which i dont do very often.
author: Nick O.

description: Yay for decent Mexican food! I was just craving a veggie burrito, and this totally satisfied my craving as a burrito with the standard ingredients, including rice, beans (your choice), cheese, lettuce, tomato, sour cream, and guacamole. It was only $5.25, and you could choose if you wanted a regular tortilla or a spinach one. They also give you chips, and there are a number of salsas you could have. They take cards, and they are SUPER fast. I was in and out in maybe 3 minutes. It was just what I wanted!
author: Sara W.

description:
Great Mexican food at an even better price.  I had a huge salad with steak for like $6 and it was soooo good.  

All the food we ordered looked and tasted fresh and wonderful!

Plus it's hard to find good cheap Mexican food in the sunset.
author: Megan L.

description:
Being only about 1 block away from my parent's house, I find myself getting take-out lunch here several times a month. With two little ones in tow, it makes lunchtime easy when visiting the grandparents. 

The service is hit-or-miss but the food is pretty consistent. My parents like their chicken and veggie burritos, my husband really likes their carnitas, I like their chicken tacos & super nachos (oink oink), and my daughter loves the side order of pinto beans and rice. Good food & good prices.
author: Lizelle G.

description:
As far as burritos go this one was nothing special.  But really, what other choice do I have in the Inner Sunset?  If La Fonda has the highest rated for Mexican food in the Inner Sunset I don't even want to think about trying the other places.

I'm sure I'll be back though.
author: Jeff S.

description: I wish I could give this place 5 stars.... but a burrito is something so easy and simple to make, yet they messed up on mine :[ I would have to say though, they make your food in a blink of an eye, it's crazy amazing fast. But maybe that's when mistakes happen. I ordered a super burrito which comes with all the fixings of guac, sour cream, beans, etc. But tell me why I didn't have that in my burrito? I was upset but again, maybe because they were working too fast... I'm hesitant to, but I may give this place another try just because it's so close to where I live.
author: Eugenia G.

description:
Extremely mediocre. Is that an oxymoron?

Food was really just.. so.. whatever.. I've already forgotten about it.

The service was very fast and friendly, the place was clean and bright, and the prices were quite good. 

And yet... there's just something kinda depressing about mediocre Mexican food.
author: Laura P.

description:
I'm no burrito expert, but I do know that La Fonda's veggie super burritos (without beans and lettuce) are the bomb. Get one with a spinach wrap--the green tortilla makes a nice contrast with the red salsa & rice. 

The fresh limeade is also really yummy on a hot day.
author: Liz L.

description:
Clean... yet not too gringo... a rare, and very pleasing combination! Their giant burritos run from $4 to about $7, and they're packed with really fresh/great tasting ingredients. My only complaint is the carrots and peas that they mix in with the rice. I just don't dig that stuff, but it wasn't too bad... so no big whoop.

One bit of advice - don't sit upstairs, unless you're a cold blooded lizard type of creature. It gets so GD hot up there.
author: Alex C.

description:
Wavers around okay and passable, the Peter of Fondas.

Haven't returned in awhile, apparently I'm not really fonda it.
author: GIR ..

description:
Who says you have to go to the Mission to get a good burrito?  or quesadilla?  or salsa?  I LOVE the salsa bar, which I don't say about most places.  Perfectly spicey and yet also accessible to my friend with the wimpy mouth.  The place is cheery on those cold, foggy days when only a little bit of sunny south of the border food will make things better.
Plus I don't have to take 2 trains to get there!
author: Suzanne G.

description: Excellent burritos, conveniently (or inconveniently, depending on how you look at it) located across the street from where I work out.  Sort of negates the whole gym-going experience to plow through a super burrito immediately after class but I figure, at least I worked out first, right?
author: Amanda B.

description:
Yup, this place is Da Bomb.

Makin me hungry already.

Homemade tortillas and excellent salsa.

Friendly service and clean restaurant.

Yes, the Sunset DOES have decent Mexican food after all.
author: Indigo M.

description:
I don't come to the Sunset very often so when we ventured out to a bar to watch the Superbowl, It was sheer fate that brought La Fonda and I together. 

It went something like this: 

~Drinking starts at 11:30am on the dot. 
~Drinking continues. 
~Watching of the Superbowl. 
~So excited when I think the Cardinals are going to win. 
~Drinking continues. 
~Steelers score in the last 2 minutes of the game and are now surely to win. 
~Throwing of bar peanuts and snack mix at the TV. 
~ Bartender that was our friend is now in fact angry. 
~We stumble out dejected, drunk and starving. 
~ LA FONDA! 
~Ordering of Carnitas Super Burrito to ensue. 
~Pure orgasmic pleasure. 

P.S. Does anyone else think of Napolean Dynamite when they see/hear of this place? HA
author: Julia N.

description: Decent to good veggie burrito. Tasty spinach tortillas and good salsa.
author: Miriam W.

description:
I'd been living in the Inner Sunset for almost six months, when I finally stumbled into this taqueria. You see, I'd lost my taste for Mexican food for about five years after eating nothing but for far too long. It was pure burrito burnout. And then along came a great recommendation to try the tacos at Taqueria San Jose (in the Mission), and my love for corn tortillas and pollo asada was rebord. 

So I finally tried La Fonda and discovered a much better than average taqueria. The first thing you notice is that the place is very clean and the folks at the counter are really nice. I've only had the chicken tacos, and since I'm a taco purist, I just get the base model version with the tortilla, meat and salsa. Oh man, at only about $2.50, you get a heaping, and I mean heapin, mound of fresh chicken and tasty hot salsa. They prepare everything right in front of you. The prices are fare, the horchata is delicious and the chips are free. 

I highly recommend this place and I've been going about once a week for the last month.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Really good burrito for $5!  (I had spicy pork/refried/green tortilla)
Just a walk-in walk-out type place, has a few chairs/tables.
author: Wesley W.

description:
I have to say that this is one of my favorite taco places in the city. Tacos do not come in just one style (just go to D.F.) and there will be the range in terms of variety and style.  While most  places try and emulate style of little side of the road taco stands, La Fonda does not.  Rather, it is more like the tacos you get in chi-chi Mexico City taquerias that are frequented by fresas, but in a good way.

While most places have to stick to the one or two meats that they do best, la fonda has a wide variety that are all very flavorful, and not over the top.  They don't do anything perfect, but they do most very well.  It is one of the few places that I don't really use the salsa, because I usually order the cochinita or the mole, and I want to enjoy the flavor of the meat itself.  On the tacos it is especially nice because they use very good tortillas. Also, they make the best sopes I have had in a long time.

Don't get me wrong, there are great places in the Mission, but La Fonda does what it is trying to do as well as anywhere in the city.

As a final word, La Fonda stands out in terms of its service.  The people that work there seem genuinely nice, and that combined with how pleasant the space is makes it a really nice eat-in experience.
author: Nicholas E.

description:
My Fiesty Fiesta friends and I recently came to this place with the burrito eater himself (google him.)  This is one of his top rated burrito...the super burrito.  Unfortunately, I ordered before him, as did a few of my other friends and missed the memo.  Apparently you MUST order the super burrito GRILLED AND IN FOIL.  My burrito (with Carnitas) was sloppy, wet, and actually kinda cold.  I think the foil and grilled-ness would've taken care of these problems.  My friends who ordered AFTER the burrito eater benefited from his vast experiences and ordered the right way.  They LOVED their burritos.

Another note, we sat upstairs (there is very little seatng in this place) and right above the kitchen.  We were inhaling smoke for a good hour and reeked afterwards.  Next time, order GRILLED AND FOILED and sit upstairs but AWAY from the kitchen.
author: Angela S.

description:
I haven't decided if it's a solid 4 or a 3.5. Don't get me wrong: I love the food and have been back many times. Plus they're the only Mexican restaurant that serves beefy nachos in this 'hood. I think that the food is "typical", but they do a good typical. Great staff and consistent quality.

Times visited: 10+
author: Amy L.

description:
Great chicken mole!

The only thing I have tried so far is the chicken mole super burrito... and it is downright heavenly.  This is the best chicken mole I've had in a long time. 

I haven't ventured into trying anything else on their menu because I tend to order the chicken mole super burrito over and over again.  If you're a fan of chicken mole, this is your place!

Nearby Gordo and L'Avenida are okay in comparison but they just don't have the variety and that extra "something something" that La Fonda has.  Quite frankly, I find the burritos at Gordo and L'Avenida to be palatable but blase.
author: Lori R.

description:
They forgot my order!!!!
It's cold and raining outside, and it's around three thirty in the afternoon. There is one other customer inside and he already has his burrito, so I'm the only one there.
I ordered a super nacho and take a seat, waiting and waiting.
Five minutes, ten minutes, and after about twenty minutes the lady come with the nachos and said to me "Sorry we forgot your nacho in the microwave". Duh????
Wanna gave them one star but that's the only time I went there, so two star for now and I'll try again another time.
author: toto h.

description:
'Hot salsa' about as spicy as hospital tapioca; Music from the soundtrack of "Diez cosas que odio de ti." 

Three stars because: 1) They didn't poison me or spit in my food; 2) It's cheap; and 3) It's not really below average (and that doesn't speak well for Mexican food around here).  Why can't Taqueria Can Cun or El Farolito move out here?
author: Phil K.

description:
Good Burritos found in the Inner Sunset! Seriously, this place is pretty good. Although the burritos aren't A+ worthy they are a good neighborhood treat. The prices are very reasonable, $3.80 for a veggie burrito with chips. The atmosphere is pretty cool too. It has brightly colored walls, nice paintings, a cool second level, and hip latino music always playing.

The people are friendly, and its a place for a reliably good burrito. Maybe not worth going across town for, but good for us Inner Sunsetites.
author: Alex O.
